tagDescription: Report of Council on Lord Selkirk's proposal of a road in U.Canada.Not beneficial to Crown or public that proposal be acceded to.Reasons for same. Signed H.Allcock,Chairman,and certified by James Green,Secretary.(Enclosure in Hunter's to Selkirk,Sept.21,1804.)
Bill of John Bogg,debtor to Earl of Selkirk.

to John Davis. Is sorry to learn that Hubbard and Vermette have betrayed their trust. Sends Mr.Corrigal and several others to take charge of Henley House while he(Davis) goes to oppose McBean on his way to Flint Lake. Refers to the examination of Swain.
Ld.S. issues second warrant for search of arms at Ft. Wm. Examination of prisoners and Fort.
Extract of Letter to Lord Bathurst. re Field Officers of Regt. Encloses heads of proposal of which he previously stated outlines.
Apparently extracts from Journal of James White of Fort Douglas.
Memorandum of the different tradesmen's shops &c. at Fort William 1816, per Dr.Allan's statement.

Memorial sent to Du.Stewart (another copy of which was sent to Jo.Foster Ip. I.H.C.) respecting Irish emigration.Establishment of Irish Colony in U. America and aid from public purse to those willing to emigrate.Memorialist will obtain settlers if Gov't bear expense of passage to Canada.

Extract of letter to Mr.J.Boinkman (unsigned.) re Messrs. Bourke,McLean & Holte.Requests for 3 or 4 Indians to assist in tracking boats up River. Ungentlemanly conduct of Mr.Cameron.Nine Cree Indians brought from Qu'Appelle. The Settler in the foreign country.

Extract of a Conversation with Ld.P.respecting Irish Emigration. Observations on American Plan by Dug.Stewart.Emigration from Highlands of Scotland obnoxious to Government. The danger, hardships, and ridicule to which one is exposed in forming a settlement in America.
Observations by Lord Selkirk on Canadian lands granted to him in 1803.

Proposal re emigration to Canada of Selkirk's settlers. That Selkirk will at his own risk lay out considerable expense for purpose of bringing the Scottish settlers who are leaving for U.States to Canada. That unappropriated lands of Upper Canada,south west of Lake Simcoe be reserved for Highland settlers. That Gov't make conditional sale to Selkirk and that Selkirk be allowed choice of unlocated lands.

Ld.S. returns to Montreal after collecting evidence re disturbances at Red River.Arrival at Montreal of Lagimonie from R.R. with news of settlers re-establishing themselves on their farms. Ld.S. makes application for King's troops to be sent to defend R.R.

to Earl of Camden. Scroll copy of proposal of settlement in Mohawk's land on Grand River,Upper Canada. Culture of hemp. Contrast of this district to others. Introduction of settlers from U.S.'s but only with His Majesty's authority.
Declaration of John Garney. re goods stolen from Hudson's Bay Company's store at Flint Lake.
Narrative of Dr.John Allan,Surgeon Royal Navy, Medical Attendant with Lord Selkirk from 1815 to 1820. Accompanied Lord Selkirk and family to America in 1815. Arrived at Montreal
Descriptive list of specimens of rock and soil.
Indictment for robbery against Messrs. Lamarre, Hesse Heupe, Deschamps, Jr. and Sr.,Joseph Deschamps,Alexander MacDonell and Toussaint Vandry. Two witnesses.
to James White,Surgeon at R.R.Settlement. Has received his letter sent by Mr.Wilkinson. Complains of his ill-usage and the insults he has had.
Bill of John Freeman,debtor to Earl of Selkirk.
Further Extracts from Journal of White.
Observations on abolition of slave trade in Africa. Improvement to Country Effect on tribes on Coast of Guinea.Necessity of repressing unprincipled violence and establishment of a regular government.
Unaddressed and unsigned extract of letter re issuing and serving warrants. Roads and highways. Mr.McLeod's boasts.
Letter to Lord Hobert.(Unsigned but apparently from Lord Selkirk.) re grant of Red River as place of settlement. Requests his Lordship's views re the taking of Irish Colonists instead of Scotch.
List of goods found by Mr.John Davis on his arrival at Flint Lake.

to Earl of Selkirk. Has laid contents of his letter of 24th inst. before Ld. Hobart who approves of Ld.Selkirk's plan of settlement in P.E.I.Is unable at present to give any positive assurance as to terms and conditions of granting forfeited lands.
to Earl of Selkirk. Requests that his name be mentioned as officer for Fencible Regt.and encloses letter from Major McDonald to himself.
Arrival at Drummond's Island in July.Assists at Council meeting of Indians. Ld.S. furnished with an escort.
Notes and extracts by Ld.Selkirk re Haldane's answer in Corrigal's Journal and exchange of liquor for the furs of the Indians and affray at Eagle Lake.

Letter of John Davis re the detention of C.Swain a runaway servant of the H.B.Co. John Hubbard and Joseph Vermet who have gone over the N.W.Co. with part of H.B.property. Trade at Henley; New Brunswick Morse Settlement; Kingston and Michilimackinach. Fishing tolerably prosperous. The Damas family. Encloses list of trifles.
Instruction for Archibald Mason as to the means to be employed by him in hiring men for the service of Hudson's Bay Company.2nd April 1810.
to Mr.McPharson. Has been informed of his(McPharson) being at Flint Lake. His men will deliver up foods left after desertion of N.W.Co. servants. Requests receipt of them.
Letter of Mr.W.M.Sutherland(unaddressed) re appointment of Mr.McKenzie on Staff of H.B. Co.

Letter of Lt.Gov'r Hunter to Selkirk. Accedes to his Lordship's proposition re extension of period in which Scotch settlers were to take up their land in the province. Consents to naming of deputation for fixing location for settlers.
Prince Edward Island Statement re lands(scroll.) delivered to Board of Trade.
Further Extracts from(White's Journal.)
Observations on Emigrant Regulation Act. Sent to Ld. Sidmouth. Number of passengers to a vessel. Quantity of provisions,etc.
Indictment for murder against Peter Steene Ogden, John Macdonald, witness.
Lord Selkirk's arrest on Nov'r 7th.
Agreement between Earl of Selkirk and N.W.Co. re indemnification on both sides for all damages of any of their partners,clerks or servants.
List of goods said to have been taken by Joseph Vermette.
Bill of Lackey Fallon,debtor to Earl of Selkirk.

Note.Selkirk to Pitt. Submits suggestions re administration of Provinces Upper and Lower Canada,and will be glad of Pitt's opinion on Application of Friday last as he is leaving town as soon as he can get an answer. Requests Pitt's sentiments of Emigrant Regulation Act of 1803.
Outlines of a plan for the settlement & security of Canada.
Deposition of Archibald Macdonald re debt of Isaac Greenfield to Earl of Selkirk.
Note. Selkirk to Lord Hobart. Requests return of memorial and his Lordship's sentiments on same. Will call on Ld.H.
Note re trial of Reinhard.

to Thomas Boar. State of affairs at Flint Lake last Fall.Was compelled to hide what remained of his outfit. Requests that any letters from him be given to N.W.Co.also that he (Boar) take the small parcel from England, as payment of his (Hubbard's) debt.
Letter of Alex. McLean to J.D.Cameron acknowledges receipt of letter of same date and expresses himself re his detention by Cameron.
Ld.S. leaves Montreal for R.R.
Queries relative to occupancy of land in Ireland. Given to J.Foster.
to Duncan Cameron. States that he was not author of the letters received by Cameron on 8 June and is ready for interview at any time.

Explanatory in answer to D/Y on Regt. Proposal. (Copy to Lord Bathurst.) re Observations of H.R.H. the Commander in Chief. Promotion of officers from temporary to permanent route. Ensign's half pay for officers without permanent rank. Bonus at termination of service. Service of married men.
Extract of letter(unaddressed and unsigned) re abandoning the R.R.S.(apparently from H.B.Co. servants to N.W.Co.)
Extracts from Journal.

Report of Council on petition of Alex.MacDonell of 6th Mar. 1805. Petition referred to Ex.Council by order of President. 1200 acres to be granted under table of fees of 28.Feb.1803.-(In proceedings of Upper Canada Council.)
Note addressed to Lord Hobart.(Unsigned.) re International Security of I. Requests his Lordship's sentiments on same.

Letter of Alex. MacDonald to Lord E. Respecting field officers for intended Regt. For Canada. Reference to Major Archd.MacDonald and family. Major McPherson of 2nd 78 Regt. Capt. Allan McDonald of 55th Regt. Has not been able to make a  list of any number of people as he awaits exact terms to mention to them.
Deposition of Adam Sutherland,Red River Settlement,re his detention as prisoner of N.W.Co.
List of necessaries and cost.for a soldier of the line.
Circulars to Colonels of Regiments of the Line re recruiting for rank.
Deposition of Ferdinand Chelli,servant of the H.B.Co. re the taking of their provisions and horses by the N.W.Co.
Extracts of letter re supply of arms being given to settlers. Enticements offered to H.B.Co.servants and Halfbreeds by N.W.Co.Proclamation prohibiting running of the buffalo on horseback,etc.

Invoice with a list of goods found by Mr. Davis on his arrival at Flint Lake Mar.20,1813;likewise a list of goods lost by desertion of Vermette's and Hubbard and a list of the quantity and quality of the furs brought from Flint Lake by Chas.Swain and left on the road to Henley House.
Intercourse between Ld.S & Agents of N.W.Co. in December. In 1816 accompanied Ld.S. to York, U.C.
Arrival of Ld.S. & friends at Kaministigoia River on 12 August.

Petition of Alex. MacDonell,agent for Earl Selkirk . That grant of 1200 acres of land be subject to table of fees of 28th Feb.1803 and that all additional fees charged be removed. Certified by John Small. (In proceedings of U.C.Council.)
Extracts of letter re settlers and game of R.R.S. (Unaddressed and unsigned.)
Extracts of letter from a gentleman of Red River Settlement to his wife in London re hardships in the Settlement.
gives evidence on 22 August.
Letter from James White to Alexandre MacDonell of Fort Daer. Miscellaneous subjects.
Extracts of letter re desertion of H.B.Co.settlers. (Unaddressed and unsigned.)
Deposition of Archibald Macdonald re debt of John Bates to Earl of Selkirk.
Annexed papers A.& C.to observations of Lord Selkirk,re his township in Upper Canada. Settlement of same.
Note addressed by Daniel McKenzie to Miles MacDonell. re the way he, the only Partner of the N.W.Co. in the place, could manage their goods and property.
Further Extracts from Journal of R.R.S.

Memorial of Earl of Selkirk to H.M.the King. Presented to Lord Grenville,respecting American grant of land. Refers to information of 1802 re Highland Emigration. Solicits indemnification for loss of property and expense incurred in establishing Colony of said Emigrants.
to McBean.Answer to McBean's letter of 31st March,1813. States that when blankets and other stolen property are returned, he will give receipt.

to J.D.McBean. Answer to McBean's letter of 14th April 1813. Has perused his letter and leaves affair to superior officers. Requests John Hubbard to be sent immediately; also Lafreniere and Archambo, that they may be sent to Albany Fort. Refers to C.Swain, deserter of N.W.Co.
News of Capt. Matthey and D'Orsonnens.
to Alex.Shaw. Testimonial re his (Shaw's) conduct as officer in 92nd Regt.(Enclosure in Shaw's to Earl of Selkirk.)
Extract (the commencement of which is not found) re manner in which trials are conducted in Canada.

to Earl of Selkirk. Rec'd Ld.S. correspondence of previous day re Lieut's McKenzie and McLeod and has seen Capt.McGregor and rec'd in formation about them. States Capt.McKay's expectation of Majority in McGregor's Regt.

Representation by Earl of Selkirk. Re Canadian grant to Scottish emigrants bound for United States. Surprised to find that his work in procuring settlers for Canada was not approved by Government. Suggestions re to Governor of Upper Canada.

Observations of S.America delivered to Windham & Lord Grenville. State of Spanish possessions. Government of Provinces. Total exclusion of Natives from all offices of trust or emolument. Inadequate Military force. Regulations of Old Gov't in need of repair. Re-expenditure of very little needed to bring whole territory under Br.rule. Advantages and disadvantages of same.Views of the French upon Spanish America.
to Wm.McDonald. Late permanent Sergt. 93 Regt. Respecting Marquis and Lady Stafford. Lease of land in parishes of Kildonaw and Clyne.
Bill of Roger Foy,debtor to Earl of Selkirk.
to Charles Swain. Is sending letter by John Hubbard and Vermette. Mr. McPherson will visit him(Swain) on his way to Flint Lake. Hubbard has 30 muskrat skins which he(Swain) is authorized to take.
Extracts re destruction of E. of S. and his people by a band of N.W.Co. servants.
Earl of Selkirk to the Lords Chief Justices of Courts of King's Bench & Common Pleas at Wesminster. Requests that they name the Arbitrators for Arbitration of differences between N.W.Co. and himself.
Unaddressed letter of servants of H.B.Co.at Red River Settlements(apparently to officers of N.W.Co re their conduct towards H.B.Co.)
Letter of Lord Hobart.(Unsigned but apparently to Lord Selkirk.) Extent of land at Ste. Mary's must be made according to number of settlers. Requests information as to number of settlers.
Extracts of letter re property to be taken by settlers on leaving the Colony.
Examination of Charles Swain at Albany Factory,January 25th 1813,by Thomas Thomas and Thomas Vincent.
Requests that he get grant of land and mines at S. Mary's.
Extract by Ld.Selkirk re slow progress of U.Canada Colony.
Memo. re William McD. Late Sergt.in 93rd Regt. and William Munro.
Extracts of letter from Mr.Robertson to Gov'r.Semple.
Indictment for robbery against John Haldane,Michel Rastoule,Chas.Landrie and Eustace Sabourin.
List of officers who are likely to raise men for H.M.Services.
Deposition of Archibald Macdonald re debt of John Graham to Earl of Selkirk.
Indictment for murder against Thomas McKay. Five witnesses.

Suggestions respecting Upper Canada,delivered to Windham per Sir George Shee. Abuses to Land Grants could be stopped if a population of superior description could be attracted. Scottish Highland Emigrants most desirable. Most eligible situation for settlement appears to be the South West part of U.Canada. Hemp could be grown there to great advantage. Americans should be induced to sell their lands to Scottish settlers and roads should be opened up. Land laid out in smaller lots would attract European settlers.

Memorial to Lords Sidmouth and Windham re granting of Canadian lands to Lord Selkirk in 1803.Conditions annexed.Requests that patents issued for sale of Mohawk lands on Grand River be cancelled and that Ld.Selkirk may be permitted to purchase said lands. Reasons for request.

Letter. George Williamson to Major Brown. Rec'd Col. Napier's letter enclosing one from Williamson with plan of Lord Selkirk for raising Highland Fencible Reg't to serve in Canada. Will endeavour to secure men.
Statement of furs loose in N.W.Co. stores, 11 Dec 1816.
Things which Mr. Tait will be accountable for,and things over and above the inventories.
to Earl of Selkirk. Has not obtained all information he wants,so will defer waiting on him till tomorrow.
List of John Hope.(Unaddressed.) Re Lt.McNeil of Barrow in 91st Regt. Particulars may be had from Archd. Campbell,Esqr.No.18,Suffolk St., re his qualifications.
Letter to Mr.McKenzie re ordres of Capt.d O to retire from Colony.(Unsigned.)
Observations on proposed changes of destination of Irish Catholic Emigrants bound for the U.States.The temptation of New York,Baltimore and the larger cities and towns.
Extract of letter, re efforts to re-establish the Colony. (Unaddressed and unsigned.)
Answers to queries re Militia to be sent to Canada. The amount of Artillery necessary,number of men and quantity of provisions and amount of goods for Indian presents.

Communications with Government 1805-6-7 relative to America General and Outlines of a plan for the settlement and security of Canada,1805. July 2. Low price of land and grants from Crown has caused influx of American settlers in U.& L.Canada and this is harmful to British interests. Settlers who speak other languages besides English should be encouraged. Settlements opened in Western parts of Upper Canada beyond Niagara suggested for these. Agents should be sent to Highland settlements of N.York. State to bring settlers to Canada and lay the foundation of an Aristocracy.All lands reserved by Indians should be purchased. Insrtructions to Gov'r re extent of grants require revision.
Letter of Charles Ker. (Unaddressed.) re Captain Cameron of the 9th Regt. of Fort, who is willing to raise men for majority.
Abstracts of Indictments.
Notes on Chapter III by Ld.Selkirk.
Inventory of Medicine.&c.belonging to the Red River Settlement.
List of Half Pay Officers.
Letter to Addington.(Unsigned.). Anxious to learn whether his Lordship approves of plan of settlement in U.Canada or not.
Report of Council on petition of Alex.MacDonell of 27 Jan. 1806.re grant to Ld.Selkirk of 1200 acres of land. (In proceedings of U.C.Council. )
Issues warrant for apprehension of Wm.McGillivray.
to James White. Account of taking of N.W.Fort at Gibraltar.

Suggestions on Spain presented to Lord Sidmouth. Measures advisable for Spaniards to pursue to profit by present advantages and manner in which Great Britain can best promote adoption of these measures.
Confidential statement for Lord Selkirk, from Mr.Bruce re reccruiting.Cost of maintaining regiments.

Letter of John Hope.(Unaddressed.) Has rec'd his letter of 5th. of junior officers he knows little, the senior officers are all on duty. Suggests that he apply to Ardgower for men.Thinks Col.MacDonell of 92nd Regt.will not wish to move.His reasons. Mentions Capt.Ewen McPherson,Major Dond.MacDonald,Capt. Dugall Campbell and Capt. McBarnet as capable officers. Will send result of communication with Lt.Col.Macdonald.
Explanatory Papers by Thomas Vincent of conditions at Flint Lake.
Deposition of Archibald Macdonald of R.R.S re debt of Alexander Gunn,Junr.
Notes & Extracts by Lord Selkirk. Some of which commencements and endings are not found.
List of guns and number of men required for artillery field.
Extracts re aggression of N.W.Co.against H.B.Co.servants.
to Hunter. Re proposal of road from York to Amherstburgh. Condition of roads through the Province. Gives advantageous route for new road. Expense for opening road.
Continuation of examination on 15 August.
Indictment for Robbery against Messrs. Grant, McKay, Hoole (Antoine,) and Hoole (Francois), Fraser, LaCerte and Bonhomme Montour, principals and Alex.MacDonell,Accessy.
Agreement between N.W.Co. and Earl of Selkirk re the restoration of goods in N.W.Co.'s post at Fort William belonging to the H.B.Co.
to Selkirk. Has laid his proposal re road before Executive Council. Encloses copy of report of Council on same.
to Mr.Fidler Informs him of state of affairs at Fort Daer;will be able to supply him with meat.
Letter to John Sullivan.(Unsigned.). Respecting conditions of grants in Canada and established modes of laying out same. Will be anxious to know what latitude is allowed to the Gov't of the Province.
Indictment of burglary against Alexander Stewart, Robert Henry,and Jean Baptiste Deschamps. Ferdinand Chelli,witness.
Indictment for murder against Francois Mainville, Negaribinis and Jean Baptiste Desmarais. Two witnesses.
leaves with 20 settlers for Lake La Prairie. Dec. 21. Ld.S. notified of Messrs. Coltman & Fletcher's appointment as Commissioners of Special Enquiry.
Memorandum. Alex.Stewart to Alex.Bruce. Statement of his ideas on Highland Regts. (Enclosure in Bruce to Earl of Selkirk of Feb.20.)
Extract re trials in Upper & Lower Canada.
Modifications on Regimental proposal re 6th.7th & 9th heads of proposal; conveyance of families be completed in 4 or 5 years. 10th head of proposal to be dispensed with.
Memo. re Militia.
Bill of John Bassett,debtor to Earl of Selkirk.

Proceedings in Council.Upper Canada re Ld.Selkirk's grants of land. Petition of Alex.MacDonell,Agent to Ld.S.,that deeds may be issued for grants. States His Lordship's intentions re distribution of land.Specifies lots he(MacDonell) wishes to locate.
Brief extract of Attorney General's speech. Examination of Michael Heden.
Bill of Jannet McDonald,debtor to Earl of Selkirk.
Indictment for arson against John Haldane, Charles Landrie and Michel Rastoule.
Bill of Alexander Gunn,Dr. to Earl to Selkirk.
Extract of letter(apparently to Lord Selkirk ) re abandoning the Settlement.
Proposition re the settling of Prince of Prince Edward Island. Ld.S on effect of proper inducements being offered to settlers bound for United States.
List of goods lost by the desertion of John Hubbard and Joseph Vermette.
Narrative of J.Pritchard.Relative to affairs and conditions at Fort William,York,Sault Ste. Marie and Montreal.
Bill of John Bates, debtor to Earl of Selkirk.
Extract from the Journal of Grand River near Peace River kept by the clerk in charge.
JOURNAL kept by John Hubbard at Flint Lake and left by him when he went to Mr. McBean's house.
Report of Council on Memorial of the Earl of Selkirk re alterations in future grants to himself,of waste lands of the Crown in Upper Canada.
List of Ships;their time. Captain,Admirals,and stations as given by J.M.Gladery,9th Jany,1813.

American Treaty with Western Indians. Effect on honor of Britain by leaving them( the Indians) in power of Amer.Gov't. Necessity of new line of demarcation between U.Canada and the U.S. as represented by the Amer.Government.
sets out for interior with Proclamation of Sir John Sherbrooke of 16 July.

Letter to Lord Pelham.(Unsigned and apparently from Selkirk.) Enclosed statement of his ideas re choice of situation for a colony. If Colony were successfully begun, settlers's friends would follow. Has been successful in finding in all parts of Ireland any number of Labourers willing to emigrate.
Observations by the Duke of York on S.'s proposal of Fencible Regiment.
Regimental proposal of Lord Selkirk. First scroll to Lord Bathurst. Regt. Of Fencibles to assist in war with U.S. Fourteen proposals,notes and explanatory remarks.
Duncan McNaughton's report on warrants of search in his charge.
Scroll copy to Lt.Gov'r Hunter.(Apparently from Selkirk.) Location for settlers in Shawnee Townships. Requests consent of Indians, if they have title to said land,for occupying same.
Bill of Michael Morley,debtor to Earl of Selkirk.

to John Davis. His only object in asking a receipt for articles restored was to ascertain whether his men had executed his orders. Requests the name of person or persons about whom he (Davis) complains and gives short account of conditions at Long Lake.
Extract of letter (unaddressed and unsigned) re issuing of warrant on the Gov'r;and roads and highways. (Apparently answer to above.)
List of Furs brought by C.Swain from Flint Lake and left for want of provisions on road to Henley House, as he says for payment of sum and other property taken from H.B.Stores at Flint Lake.
to Thos.Vincent. Gives an account of conditions and goods at Flint Lake. Has just finished putting seed in the ground.
Bill of Isaac Greenfield,debtor to Earl of Selkirk.

to Earl of Selkirk. Gives information respecting affairs of N.W.Co. as well as he remembers,for 2 or 3 years back,as it relates to the R.R.S. Presents given. Letters rec'd and sent.Promises made, etc, etc.
General Statement of the furniture at Fort William as observed by John Spencer and LeBlanc.
List of Blacksmith's articles for Red River Settlement.
Unaddressed and unsigned letter re treatment of patients. (Apparently those of James White.)
Letter from James White,Surgeon,unaddressed re amount of a bill which has been settled by Mr.Robertson.
Extract from letter of James White to Alex.MacDonell,Fort Daer,re treatment of one of his(White's) patients.
Extract re state of Glengarry road in Lower Canada. Has mentioned subject of expenditure on same to S.R M. and Mr. McGill.
Memo.(Apparently of Ld.S.). Lord Hobart's opinion on proposition of Mr.Sullivan. Requests that Ld.S. specify lots he has in view.
Extract of letter(unaddressed and unsigned) re agressions of N.W.Co.
Indictment for stealing above the value of 40% in a dwelling house certain persons therein being put in fear &c. Against Joseph Larocque and Benjamin Frobisher. Peter Knight,witness.
Unaddressed extract of letter(unsigned) re obtaining friendship of Halfbreeds for H.B.Co. & R.R.Settlement.
Bill of James Smith, Dr. to Earl of Selkirk.
Second proposal of Lord Selkirk of an expedition thro' Hudson's Bay for purpose of operating a diversion on the Western frontier of the United States.
List of Medicines for the use of the Hudson's Bay Company.

Original Scroll Memorial. re Irish emigration especially that of Irish Catholics to N.America. Arrangements should be made to suit their religious and national prejudices.Memorialist ready and willing to devote his services to his country.Will secure settlers if Gov't. bear expense of passage.
Affidavit of Miles MacDonell,J.P. re Betty McKay of R.R. Settlement.
Drposition of Alex. McLean re Mr.Cameron's statements re inducements of N.W.Co.to settlers in Canada.Also the burning of his, McLean's house by N.W.Co.
Deposition of Archibald Macdonald re debt of John Early to Earl of Selkirk.

Report of Council letter of Lord Hobart to Lt.Gov'r Hunter on 23rd Feb. 1803, re lands granted to Ld. Selkirk and distribution of same. Signed Peter Russell. Approved by A.Grant and certified by John Biekie. (In proceedings of U.C.Council.)
Extract of letter (unaddressed and unsigned) re conditions at Fort Daer and N.West Post at Pembina. Attack on Seraphin and Bostonois by intoxicated people.

H.Bay proposal of Military protection for Indians on the U.S.Frontier.(Sent to Lord Bathurst.). H.B.Co. willing to bear expenses of conveyance from coast of H.B. to interior and will supply some men and horses. Request that on approval of proposal, military clothing and camp equipage be sent; also goods for Indian presents.
List of Medical instruments with cost of each.
Extract of letter (unaddressed and unsigned) re search of N.W.Co.'s Fort at R.R.Forks.
to Jas.Wedderburn. Respecting regimental officers of 78th Regt.McPherson and McKay.Lt.McKenzie is nephew of Lord Seaforth and Lt.McLeod of Skye.

Indictment for arson against Francois Dechamp,Sr. and Francois Deschamps,Jr.,Joseph Deschamps,Michel Bourassa,Charles Hesse, Antoine Hoole,Jean-Bte.Desmarais, Joseph Desmarais,Bonhomme Montour,Joseph Hupe,John Early Peter Pangman and Alexander McDonell. Five witnesses.

List of names of heads of families introduced in the Province of Upper Canada by Earl of Selkirk and actually resident in Townships of Dover,certified by John Beikie.Enclosure: ( Proceedings of U.C.Council.)
Bill of Donald Sullivan,debtor to Earl of Selkirk.
Deposition of Duncan McNaughton re taking of his mare from him by N.W.Co.
Deposition of Hector MacNeil,clerk in service of N.W.Co.re his obligatory duties while in service of said Company and the Co.'s treatment of several H.B.Co.'s servants.
Letter. Alex.Bruce to Lord Selkirk. Found it impossible to see letter of service.Will call.

Indenture made between Daniel McKenzie and Earl of Selkirk giving over all H.B.Co. goods in N.W.Co. post at Fort William except the furs packed for exportation for which Earl of Selkirk is to pay a sum of money equal to cost of goods.
A proposal tending to the permanent security of Ireland in a Memorial addressed to H.M.Secretary of State &c,&c., by the Earl of Selkirk.
Scroll Letter to Lord Holland re the boundaries between Louisiana and British American Dominions.
Memorandum for Lord Selkirk by Lieut. Col.Stewart respecting the raising of a Highland Regiment for Canada.
to Earl of Selkirk. Terms for raising Canadians Fencibles. Encloses Acts of Parliament relative to the allowance in lieu of half-pay to subalterns of Militia.
to Earl of Selkirk. Messrs.McPherson and McKay of 78th Regt. His likelihood of seeing Col.Torrens.McWhir's presentation and Mr.Murray's resignation.
Letters to Lord Hobart. (Unsigned.) apparently from Selkirk,re grant of St. Mary's and mines there. Description of land requested. Can secure sufficient number of settlers.
Note " " IV " " "
Unsigned letter to late settlers of R.R.S. and servants of N.W.Co.at R.R.Forks.(apparently from officers of H.B.Co re the unlawful proceedings of the N.W.Co.against their servants.
Inventory of medecine at Fort William, October 1816

Indictment for stealing in boats on a navigable River against Cuthbert Grant, Thomas McKay, Roderick McKenzie, Pater Pangman, Francois Deschamps, Paul Primau, Louis LaCerte and Alexander MacDonell. Three witnesses.
Abstract of the population of the Barony of Granard including the town of Granard in the County of Longford, Ireland.
to Earl of Selkirk. re Lt.Col.Stewart's ideas on Highland Regt.Encloses copy of circular of Commander-in-Chief to Col.'s in Regts. in 1804.

Letter of Lt.Governor P.Hunter to Earl of Selkirk. Re granting of land to families from Scotland and Wales now in New England and the State of New York.States King's orders. Quantity of land to each family.People particularly recommended to Selkirk and lands acceptable to same.
Deposition of George Sutherland. (duplicate of page 13381.)
to Earl of Selkirk. H.R.H. Duke of York does not approve of Selkirk's plan to raise Regt. for N.America.
List of Indian words and phrases with translations.
Extract of letter James White to James Sutherland of Qu'Appelle;re settlers under MacDonell's charge. Mr.Pritchard's work with the Freemen and relates to the affair of Seraphin and Bostonois.

Memorandum from Lord Gamden. re Prince Edward Island and Upper Canada. Ld.Selkirk that Governors of the two Co.'s be given directions regarding grants to emigrants. Success of Colonies hope of re-grant of lots on which quit rents have not been paid.
Observations on H.B.Territory in America presented to Lord Liverpool.Emigration of Irish Settlers encouraged.

Letter to Rt. Hon.Henry Addington.(Unsigned.). Has made it a study to devise means of attracting people to Canada. Annexes sketch of proposal to explain his ideas,and requests that he(Addington) fill in the blanks if he approves.
to Pitt. Encloses representation re Canadian grant. Refers to proposal sent to Lord Camden on Feb'y 4th re introduction of Scotch settlers residing in U.S. to Canada.
Extract of letter (unaddressed and unsigned) but apparently to Ld.S. from James White, Surgeon at R.R.,re Mr. McDonald's work in the Colony and his own resignation.

to Selkirk. Acknowledges receipt of letter of 9th transmitting copy of proposals made to Mr.Addington. States that emigration of Br.Subjects can only be countenanced by H.M. Gov't.when the intention to emigrate has been manifested.
Annexes copy of letter from Selkirk to Gov'r Gore.
called for examination.
List of officers, their rank and Regts.
Encounter at Gate of Fort William.
Proposals to raise Corps of Highland Fencibles in the County of Glengarry,U.Canada. Number of men and their rank.Rules and Regulations.
Extract of letter re assertions of Capt.Grant against certain settlers at R.R. (Unaddressed and unsigned.)
Indictment for burglary and robbery against John Thompson, Joseph Chartier, Jean Marie Boucher, Pierre Paul Samuel Black,Joseph Paul, Pierre Boucher & Jean Baptiste Durocher, John McLeod, witness.
Bill of John Graham,debtor to Earl of Selkirk.
to Lord Ellenborough. Encloses letter.Adressed officially. Trusts the step he has taken is not far out of the common path.
Observations supplementary to a memorial relative to the security of Ireland,by the Earl of Selkirk.
(In proceedings of U.C.Council.) Petition of Alex. MacDonell that a patent for 1200 acres of land may be issued to Lord Selkirk. Certified a true copy by John Small.
Bill of Thomas Seemoor,debtor to Earl of Selkirk.
furs sent to Montreal for purpose of helping in evidence on Aug 28th.Clerks of N.W.Co. also set out for Montreal.
List of officers submitted to the Earl of Selkirk and recommended for H.B.Expedition.
Extract of R.E.Edgeworth on Irish emigration. Conditions of agriculture in education. Prices of food, etc. in Ireland.
Letter to Lord Hobart. (Unsigned.) Apparently from Selkirk. Has engaged settlers for Canada. Is sure of 100 families. Will wait for specific assistance for taking it upon himself to emigrate.
to Hobart. Has stated to Mr.Addington the importance of immediate emigration. Requests his Lordship's answer as he is leaving shorthly for U.States.

Menoir on Irish emigration transmitted Nov. 19th to Lord Sidmouth.Emigration of Roman Catholics ought to be encouraged.Tendency to migrate southwards on account of difficulty in obtaining farm land. Arrangements for communicating saleable lands in South of Ireland,might be made to Protestants in the North. System of holding land through middlemen fast disappearing. Inducements of some value should be offered to settlers who will emigrate to Canada.
Extracts of letter re settlers in foreign country.Mr.Cameron's popularity.
Deposition of Alex.McLean of Red River re inducements offered by Mr. Duncan Cameron to those who would go as settlers to Canada.Also the threats of the N.W.Co.servants to burn his house.
Extract of Deposition re outrageous conduct of N. W. Co. against Deponent.
sent as prisoners to Montreal. Several clerks of N.W.Co. arrive at Ft. William.
Sept. 7th.Mr. Johnston arrives from Ste. Maries. Meteorological Journal taken from Peter Fidler at time of Gov'r. Semple's death found in Mr.A.N.McLeod's room.
Inventories of stock in Red River Settlement & N.W.Co. property by Messrs. Pritchard, Spencer in Sept. 1816 and by Messrs. Murphy & Spencer in May 1817.
Deposition of John McVicar of R.R.S. re intentions of N.W.Co.towards H.B.Co.
Extract of deposition apparently duplicate of deposition on page 13391.
Descriptions and explanations of new kinds of stoves.
Extracts re purchase of H.B.Stock by Earl of Selkirk.

Extract of Deposition(Commencement and ending of which are not found) (possibly of Dr.John Allan,R.N.,Surgeon to Ld. Selkirk in 1815-1820) re delivery to Ld.S. by Reinhard himself of his statement of connection with N.W.Co. and murder of Owen Keveney on November 3rd. Warrant of arrest of Ld. Selkirk. Warrant of arrest for J.D. Campbell. Warrant of arrest for J.D.Campbell and search made for him.News from Montreal received by Ld.Selkirk while on the road to R.R. from Ft.William,etc.
Further notes by Ld.S. re providing an asylum in British North America for emigrants who were likely to resort to the U.States.
leaves for Ste. Maries again.McKenzie purchases provisions from McGillivray at Michilimackinac.
Memorandum of John Macdonald. Recommendation of Lt.-Col.Archibald McLaine of 7th W. India Regt., and Lt.- J.McLean of 79th Regt. for Lord Selkirk's Corps.

Observations on state and Conditions of Europe since the French Revolution. Necessity of proper defence. Re-establishment of Empire of Germany. Kingdom of Hungary as an indemnity for German Dominions of Bavaria.Annexation of Turkey to Austria and Russia.Employment of armies in active operations in preparation of any counter-revolution that may break forth.
to Wm.McDonald.re Rent of Marquis of Stafford's land. Men that Wm.McDonald may obtain for His Majesty's service.
to Earl of Selkirk. Requests that schedules of N.W.Co property be sent to Montreal as soon as ready. Is fully satisfied with inventories taken by Messrs. Pritchard, Kenedy and Spencer.
Extract of letter(apparently to Lord Selkirk) from one of R.R.S. physicians) re care of Emigrants during the winter and appointment of a successor in his place.
Bill of John Early,debtor to Earl of Selkirk.
Deposition of George Sutherland re the surrender of himself and several others to the N.W.Co.
Apparently a list of agreements between H.B.Co.and N.W.Co.

Letter to General Hunter,U.Canada (Unsigned.) re resignation of Mr.MacDonell from Sheriffdom of York and appointment of successor.Has lead Mr.McLean to believe he would get the position.Requests Gen.Hunter's reasons for not appointing him.
Extract of letter giving sketch of proceedings of N.W.Co. for destruction of Colony. (Unaddressed and unsigned.)
to John Davis. Has received his letter of 15th May.Papers re Vermette and Hubbard to be laid before Committee.
Journal of (Red River Settlement.)
Arrangement proposed to N.Vansr 28th August 1812 re the Irish Catholic Church. Dangers from cession of political power to Irish Catholics diminished through satisfactory arrangement.
